note.body:
I've tried these steps and it worked at rhel8. 
1. setup a file namely `copypath`in the path`~/.local/share/nautilus/scripts/copypath` 
2. add the following code: `# !/bin/sh echo -n "$NAUTILUS_SCRIPT_SELECTED_FILE_PATHS" | tr -d '\n' | xsel -b -i` 
3. chmod the `copypath` 
4. run command:`nautilus -q` **After doing these steps,right click a file, you will see "scrips" option, and then click "copypath" the correct file path will be copied in clipboard**
![image](/uploads/b1fd404ea9d5bf77876532f953e9f124/image.png)
Now, we need to bind short key to `copypath`. **The shortcut configuration file is \~/.config/nautilus/scripts-accels and here you can define your custom shortcuts.（If it doesn't exist `scripts-accels`,creat it）** Then,add `<Control><Shift>c copypath`,and rerun `nautilus -q`.And it worked.The picture above correctly show the shortcut key `Shift+Control+C`

target_title: Initial load of folders with many items is too slow on HDDs

note.body:
Er, it’s a little stressful to be parachuted in here by name, to be honest, so apologies if I’m brusque: the only real way to get an answer to a profiling question like this is for someone to sit down and profile the problem, with the code in front of them, work out the hot paths, and then work out the optimisation possibilities.

Asking me for a drive-by opinion of how to fix it is not going to result in a magical answer that you will like.

From my knowledge of `thumbnail_verify()`, my guess would be that it’s inherently a bit slow because it has to mmap each thumbnail PNG, parse it to extract its `tEXt` metadata fields, and then compare them to the source file for validity. This is [a part of the thumbnail spec](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/thumbnail-spec/latest/modifications.html) and I don’t believe it can be skipped *if* you ask GIO for any of the thumbnail attributes for a `GFileInfo`.

I suggest you might want to explore splitting the metadata load for a directory: query for the files and most of their display metadata in one `g_file_query_info()` call (as is currently done), but don’t request any thumbnail attributes. Then asynchronously query for the thumbnail attributes in a second `g_file_query_info()` call, so the `thumbnail_verify()` calls don’t block retrieving the info necessary for displaying the files (with a placeholder thumbnail) in the Nautilus window.

Apologies if that’s what’s already done, or if I’ve misinterpreted the situation. I’ve only spent a couple of minutes on this because it’s not something I’ve chosen to work on.

target_title: Initial load of folders with many items is too slow on HDDs

note.body: Hi @pwithnall, would you happen to have some insights on why [GIO's `thumbnail_verify`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/blob/HEAD/gio/thumbnail-verify.c#L225-253) is so slow here, and whether this is actually a GIO bug rather than a "Nautilus using GIO wrong" kind of issue? The only ticket I could find related to that function is https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/issues/1314 but that doesn't sound directly related.

target_title: Fix crash if file or dialog is NULL while info_provider_idle_callback is running
update_file_info_full crashes nautilus with a segfault (even with example from doc page)

note.body:
Detailed description on how to reproduce this issue:

- install Fedora 41
- install `nautilus-python`
- copy [test.py](/uploads/4becd588cc4db8294e9154813e814224/test.py) to `~/.local/share/nautilus-python/extensions/`
- create an empty folder and open a terminal and run `mkdir test_{1..500}` to create a lot of empty folders in your new directory
- kill nautilus with `nautilus -q`
- restart nautilus with `nautilus --no-desktop`
- navigate to your folder
- immediately go back to the parent folder, i.e. press `alt+arrow-key-up`
- nautilus should crash with `Segmentation fault (core dumped)`

For me it crashes on the first enter and leave, maybe you have to re-enter and leave the directory multiple times. It is important that `update_file_info_full` is still in progress while leaving the directory, hence the many directories.

target_title: update_file_info_full crashes nautilus with a segfault (even with example from doc page)

note.body:
It is apparently not possible to reproduce this issue with a regular build from the `main` branch or any of the tags, i.e. `47.0` or `46.2`. So I tried another approach and directly built the Fedora and Ubuntu packages with an additional patch file.

With some `g_warning` outputs I was able confirm that the `file` is `NULL` in `finish_info_provider` when the crash happens.

Here is a fix for the issue: https://gitlab.gnome.org/philippun1/nautilus/-/commit/786253eadbc624700bca621ace65e7c6d2f613c3

I assume that this crash https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/-/issues/3505#note_2200991 had the same reason with `directory` being `NULL` so I added a check for that as well.

I have tested it with Fedora 40 + Nautilus 46.2, Fedora 41 + Nautilus 47.0 and Ubuntu 24.04 + Nautilus 46.2. I was able to reproduce the original issue and could also confirm that the issue is gone if I install the patched packages with the commit above for all three test cases.

Instead of crashing I now get the following output:
```
$ nautilus --no-desktop
[...]
update_file_info_full
update_cb

(org.gnome.Nautilus:9707): nautilus-async-jobs-WARNING **: 00:57:39.457: Unexpected NULL file
update_file_info_full
update_cb
[...]
```

note.body:
> Now, if it was actually making a difference, then GTK would be screwing up somewhere and we'd need to fix that.

I actually see CPU time spent in repeat nodes (and off-screen) when the texture is smaller in the profiler which disappears when enlarging the checker image. There's an example app attached in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/-/issues/7182 which is a much simpler reproducer for this than nautilus.

target_title: Improve Grid View Thumbnails Scrolling Performance

note.body:
"Excessive tiling" doesn't matter:

1. GTK optimizes a repeat of a full texture to a texture lookup with a repeat address mode. See [VkAddressMode](https://registry.khronos.org/vulkan/specs/1.3-extensions/man/html/VkSamplerAddressMode.html) for details or [glSamplerParameter](https://docs.gl/es3/glSamplerParameter).

2. That in turn is handled deep down in GPU hardware, where the pixel to sample when repeated is computed via `frac (coord) * image_size`.
 
And that code doesn't care if the texture is de-facto repeated or not.

Now, if it was actually making a difference, then GTK would be screwing up somewhere and we'd need to fix that.  

(We might have optimizations in place that skip the repeat node when not needed, but those are to avoid cases where we don't already start with a repeatable texture in step (1) - like when the texture isn't aligned or when we're repeating more complex things like text)

target_title: Improve Grid View Thumbnails Scrolling Performance

note.body:
It also doesn't necessarily support all the file formats of gdk-pixbuf. I think for now we fall back to gdk-pixbuf but that might change.

This whole code should probably just use [gdk_pixbuf_new_from_stream_at_scale_async()](https://docs.gtk.org/gdk-pixbuf/type_func.Pixbuf.new_from_stream_at_scale_async.html)?

target_title: Low FPS, very slow scrolling in grid view (icons view) in large folders (2000 files), even with thumbnails turned off

note.body:
So what the code basically does is create a new Texture every frame, which means GTK has to send the texture data to the GPU again, which apparently requires converting it from RGB to RGBA as your GPU like many GPUs doesn't understand gdk-pixbuf's RGB format and then sending the converted data to the GPU complete with memory allocation negotiation between GPU and CPU, which is what the syscalls were about.  
So you've essentially disabled GTK's thumbnail texture cache. Good to know that it is actually worthwhile. :wink: 

I think it'd be useful to go through the whole Nautilus codebase and replace usages of `GdkPixbuf` with `GdkTexture`. That way you won't just find a lot of slow things, you'll also get rid of all the workarounds in the code that exist to convert from pixbufs to cairo or snapshots - code that hasn't been touched since the Gnome 2 days basically. And there's no reason anymore to use `GdkPixbuf` for anything but load/save.

And even for load/save you may want to switch from gdk-pixbuf to [libglycin](https://gitlab.gnome.org/sophie-h/glycin), as Glycin uses `GdkTexture` natively so there's no longer any conversion to/from pixbufs necessary.  
I have no idea if it implements all the features of gdk-pixbuf that you need yet though. It also certainly supports different file formats if that matters for you.

target_title: Improve Grid View Thumbnails Scrolling Performance

note.body:
GdkTexture does not check if the bytes contain a valid image and since we are parsing untrusted thumbnails this might be an issue.

cc @sophie-h

target_title: Improve Grid View Thumbnails Scrolling Performance
Low FPS, very slow scrolling in grid view (icons view) in large folders (2000 files), even with thumbnails turned off

note.body:
I figured out the reason for slow thumbnails: We're constantly generating new textures from stored `GdkPixbuf`s and then `GtkSnapshot`ting them to `GdkPaintables` to be used in the `GtkPicture`. This causes textures to be constantly created and discarded when changing thumbnails of a grid cell. Code: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/-/blob/9cf20f730018142a434e230fbc0f1484254a873b/src/nautilus-file.c?page=5#L4765-4796

If we store a texture instead of a pixbuf, about half the usage graph disappears.

Before (scrolling with thumbnails enabled, ~15FPS):

![Screenshot_From_2024-11-25_12-29-14](/uploads/ed804556cccc408d77c445a1c686f037/Screenshot_From_2024-11-25_12-29-14.png)

After (scrolling with thumbnails enabled after removing pixbufs, ~70FPS):

![Screenshot_From_2024-11-25_12-29-27](/uploads/8eff659091161af1f3a7da4d4320a60a/Screenshot_From_2024-11-25_12-29-27.png)

target_title: When copying / moving a symbolic link between a remote directory (SFTP, webdav, etc.) and a local path, Nautilus tries copying the symlink instead of the target file

note.body:
Sorry, as usual with GNOME's Gitlab instance, for reasons I can't figure out, I didn't get notifications of these replies despite the fact that it's _my_ issue AND I have "Notifications" switched on.

@antoniof 

> Actually, in some cases, copying the symlink as-is is exactly what the user wants. Imagine this scenario: I want to backup your \~/Documents folder into a remote machine. The file paths in the remote machine are going to be exactly the same; I expect the symlinks in the copied directory tree shall keep working as expected.

I think if you're doing backups with Nautilus drag-and-drop, you've got bigger problems, but that's neither here nor there.

AFAICT _nothing_ else copies symlinks intact by default:

1. `rsync` will completely ignore symlinks (logging messages about non-regular files). It has command-line options to enable every other conceivable behavior (because of course it does).
2. `scp` in recursive (`-r`) mode will dereference them and copy the target file / target directory contents.
3. KDE Dolphin will dereference and copy the full contents, when symlinked files (or directories containing symlinked files) on an `sftp://` mount are dragged into a local directory and "Copy here" or "Move here" is selected. ("Link here" will create a `.desktop` file linking to the remote path, something Nautilus no longer supports.) I haven't tested symlinked _directories_, but my money is on "it creates a regular directory and copies the contents".

I don't have access to **two** Macs or Windows machines, to test how their native file-managers handle the equivalent structures, but I'd be shocked if it's anything close to "re-create remote symbolic links locally". (Actually I question whether a Windows machine viewing a remote share could even _see_ that something was linked, instead of just registering it as the target directory/file.)

I could maybe get behind some sort of logic where Nautilus _checks_ whether the link target exists on the local machine, and links to it if it does, but otherwise dereferences the link instead of creating broken ones... though that already seems like a fragile approach. But _unquestioningly_ re-creating links, even when they're broken, isn't so much fragile as cracked.

target_title: Merge Starred and Bookmarks

note.body:
I think if we know the reason for which `Starred` feature was introduced, we can have some clarity here. No user documentation on this doesn't help either.

Having just 2 level of bookmarks (as you've described) with different names in the UI is confusing.

target_title: Merge Starred and Bookmarks

note.body:
I believe this has been discussed a couple of times in the project's chatroom over the past few years, and personally I disagree with this idea. To me, bookmarks have much more flexibility and purpose (including the ability to give them custom names, and for them to be always present directly in the sidebar) and they never get messed up by moves or renames on the filesystem, unliked starred items.

I have been using Nautilus' customizable sidebar bookmarks for over 20 years, and have recently started using "starred" files and folders _in addition_ to that, but they are absolutely not for the same purposes.

The way I see it, bookmarks are a "tier 1" navigation tool, whereas starred items are "tier 2"; complementary, but not the same. The bookmarks feature is well-defined and pretty much bug-free, whereas the stars feature still has a lot of bugs and missing parts; for example, implementing #3189 would give starred files & folders much more purpose within the specific context of the views.

target_title: File Chooser: In saving mode, directly typing launches a search instead of renaming the file

note.body: I wonder if the solution, in addition to #3597 (which is useful in other situations as well), would be that _when in filechooser save mode_ Nautilus should default to focusing the filename entry (with its text "without file extension" pre-selected, i.e. "ready to type-to-overwrite-the-text"). At least, that is how the GTK4 (and GTK3) filechoosers behaved: by default, the filename was focused and selected, and you had to actively hit `Ctrl+F` if you wanted to switch to search mode.

note.body:
>That would only make sense if the first item was already selected by default (which is not a bad idea). But if no item is selected, i.e. the selection is at "point zero", pressing right should make the selection go from item zero (no item) to item one (or at least I find it making sense).

Another benefit is that it makes clear where your selection is when you're navigating via keyboard. So that when I open a new tab via Ctrl+T, or open a bookmark via pressing Enter on an item, it's easier to think my next action.

A comparison is when you open a folder by pressing Ctrl+Enter, where the focus doesn't change from the current selected folder. Also, when I then Ctrl+Tab to the opened folder, I know right away where the focus is if I am on a special folder (Public and Templates).

To add, opening a special folder by Ctrl+Enter versus by pressing Enter shows different selection behaviors.

1. Open Nautilus > Press Down > Press Enter
2. See that nothing is selected
3. Press Alt+Up > Press Ctrl+Enter > Press Ctrl+Tab
4. See that the button is selected

note.body:
That would only make sense if the first item was already selected by default (which is not a bad idea). But if no item is selected, i.e. the selection is at "point zero", pressing right should make the selection go from item zero (no item) to item one (or at least I find it making sense).

I agree that when pressing down, if there are multiple lines of items, it might be logical to some people to go to the second line. But again, if the first item on the first time was already selected, it would be even more logical.

Would selecting the first item by default make sense to you? I think it would make all the other problems disappear, because then it would be visually clear (while now it's not).

target_title: nautilus sometimes crashes when opening a folder

note.body:
Same problem for me after upgrading Fedora 41 with Gnome 47.1 and X11.

If I open Files (nautilus) sometimes it works and sometimes not. It often works when opening nautilus directly. 

Crashes sometimes on resize. Almost consistently crashes when opening from another program e.g. Firefox "open downloads".

I tried logging debug messages running nautilus from terminal (G_MESSAGES_DEBUG=all nautilus > naut.log), and logging. No errors. When crashing also no errors, just seem like an endless loop.

I also had other glitches, so started suspecting the akmods nvidia driver:
Gdk-INFO: 14:47:05.507: Vulkan: Loader Message: Failed to find vkGetDeviceProcAddr in layer "libVkLayer_MESA_device_select.so"
Gdk-INFO: 14:47:05.507: Vulkan: Loader Message: vkCreateDevice layer callstack setup to:
Gdk-INFO: 14:47:05.507: Vulkan: Loader Message:    <Application>
Gdk-INFO: 14:47:05.507: Vulkan: Loader Message:      ||
Gdk-INFO: 14:47:05.507: Vulkan: Loader Message:    <Loader>
Gdk-INFO: 14:47:05.507: Vulkan: Loader Message:      ||
Gdk-INFO: 14:47:05.507: Vulkan: Loader Message:    <Device>
Gdk-INFO: 14:47:05.507: Vulkan: Loader Message:        Using "NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3060 Ti" with driver: "/usr/lib64/libGLX_nvidia.so.0"

I then tried to update the NVidia driver (following https://rpmfusion.org/Howto/NVIDIA), but was already on the newest version (565.57.01).

I was using X11 and not Wayland, because it had been very unstable with Wayland. After switching to Wayland, I can no open nautilus without problems, even from other programs, and I can resize etc. with no crashes. Now the logs do not show anything on gdk-INFO.

And now Wayland runs stable on my system, so I will stick to that. Just wanted to elaborate on my findings.

I think this dialog should never be shown. There is already a Spinner in the sidebar corresponding to the partition being mounted, which should suffice. An improvement would be to show a placeholder (Loading..) page in the nautilus main view, than a dialog (which feels like old UX design).

To reproduce, click the external disk partition in sidebar multiple times to mount. Subsequent clicks will trigger this dialog.

target_title: Can't mark `.jar` files as executable
Nautilus remember view

note.body:
The biggest use case for this feature in my opinion is the `Downloads` folder.

For example:
I prefer to sort my folders by `name` and to view them on the `grid view`.

This makes a lot of sense for pretty much all the folders in my system, and **I do agree that when I change the view settings I do expect them to apply to all folders.**

However, the Downloads folder is always annoying to me. I always need to change the view settings when going to that folder, since a grid sorted by name doesn't make sense when viewing it.


So, in my usage, the Downloads folder:

- must be visualized in a different way when comparing to most other directories
- is frequently accessed

This leads me to have to **constantly switch back and forth between view configurations**, or to just settle with setting that I don't like during a session.


A much better ux would be:
- set the view settings to something that makes sense to me
- **occasionally**, when I need more detail or different sorting settings change it.



---------


This gets even more apparent now that we have https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/-/issues/3401 


Since the Downloads folder is a common directory to interact with when using a file picker.


------




**I know this is highly unlikely to get implemented**, but I also would love to also have the ability to group the Downloads folder, like other file managers such as Dolphin allows us to do


![image](/uploads/09eed55b26924773249f7faab3f4c95c/image.png)



-----


That being said, I'd be happy to implement this feature in way that makes sense to the project if I've got approval from the project maintainers/design team.

target_title: Can't mark `.jar` files as executable

note.body:
.jar files can be marked as executable like any other file, and they *need* to be marked as executable when opening them with the Open JDK runtime.

When the Open JDK runtime is installed, they can be run graphically from Nautilus by opening the file with the runtime. But if they aren't marked as executable, Open JDK will give you an error message (at least on Ubuntu).

![image](/uploads/cf79ce25c1bb7ec7b5142d7d8cba540c/image.png)

This makes sense, as .jar files can cause harm like any other executable file, so you better make sure you don't execute them accidentally.

But having to run `chmod +x` on the terminal, because the "executable" permission switch is hidden for .jar files, makes whole idea of being able to graphically launch .jar files with the Open JDK runtime pointless, which is a pity.

target_title: Can't mark `.jar` files as executable

note.body: A jar file is never an executable file. It's an archive of files. You need the Java executable on your system to run it. This makes no sense - it's like marking every Python or PHP file as executable and expecting that it will be executed by the corresponding PHP or Python executable.

target_title: Custom bookmark symbolics in the sidebar?

note.body:
Though definitely not a problem by any means, it would be a great feature to add on Nautilus.

As for symbolic icons, we're currently designing tons of all-purpose & app-specific symbolic icons (that adhere to GNOME HIG) over at [Morewaita](https://github.com/somepaulo/MoreWaita) as an expanded companion to GNOME's Adwaita icon set, so you wouldn't have to worry about maintaining something other than what GNOME or we already provide. I think having the ability to at least be able to change the symbolic icons in the sidebar would be a good first step.

target_title: Custom bookmark symbolics in the sidebar?

note.body:
Is this a problem though? File managers on other systems get by with a mix of generic bookmarks and special folders in the sidebar/bookmarks/pinned location.

I can't say I'm enthusiastic about making and maintaining (i.e. keeping futureproof to style changes) a symbolic icon set to ship along with nautilus simply for use with bookmarks.

target_title: Can't easily add a folder to bookmarks in the file chooser

note.body:
I can confirm that dragging and dropping in Nautilus to create a bookmark doesn't work.

Also, what I would consider more, related bugs:

1. If you drag a folder, wanting to add a bookmark for it, and let go over bookmark, the actual content of the dragged folder gets copied. In my opinion, this is never what the user wants, and should not be allowed to happen.
1. I can't reorder bookmarks, the icon freezes after the drag is started.
1. Dragging is wonky generally. The folder state "freezes" in the process, during the dragging, and doesn't interact with the underlying environment. The icon stays where the dragging was begun. This is a more general issue, also seen when for example dragging a folder from Nautilus to Audacious, to add to a playlist.

target_title: Sidebar sometimes breaks after clicking rearrangeable folders bookmarks too quickly

note.body:
Mutter stops all protocol exchanges for the dnd operation after the wl_data_device.start_drag. Weston sends a wl_data_source.cancelled to the client, allowing the client to proceed:
```
[ 636717.442] {Default Queue} wl_pointer#17.button(169, 14316535, 272, 1)
[ 636817.931] {Default Queue} wl_pointer#17.button(170, 14316635, 272, 0)
[ 636818.529] {Default Queue}  -> wl_data_device_manager#10.create_data_source(new id wl_data_source#46)
[ 636818.595] {Default Queue}  -> wl_data_source#46.offer("application/x-gtk-local-dnd")
[ 636818.615] {Default Queue}  -> wl_data_source#46.set_actions(2)
[ 636818.635] {Default Queue}  -> wl_data_device#19.start_drag(wl_data_source#46, wl_surface#8, wl_surface#31, 169)
[ 636827.420] {Default Queue} wl_data_source#46.cancelled()
[ 636827.594] {Default Queue}  -> wl_data_source#46.destroy()
```
This may point to mutter as the culprit.

Group parttions by disk in sidebar

note.body:
1. This discussion is mainly that we should group partitions belonging to a disk together (in multiple disk case), and not group partitions across disks together (global partition sort). Refer above partition layout and the screenshots.
 
2. Although I agree on the `partition / FS label` being empty. In that case, if we sort partitions within a disk by disk partition number (say, `sda1`, `sda2`, `sda5` in that order etc) as discussed in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/-/issues/3553, then we can display:

   - `PARTITION / FS LABEL` (if available) as sidebar label and the actual partition path (`/dev/sda1`) as tooltip on hover, and
   - `/dev/sda1` as sidebar label if `PARTITION / FS LABEL` if NOT available.

 Note: Partition numbering might not match with disk order layout in some cases. (e.g. `sda7` might be before `sda6` in actual disk sector layout).

target_title: Draft: filename-validator: Warn when spaces are detected at beginning/end

note.body:
That could work, a few remarks though:
- Is it UTF-8 friendly or will it be triggered by multi-byte unicode characters ending with `0x20`?
- Is there a way to catch more invisible characters? E.g. there are whitespaces of varying size and breakability, tabs, modifier characters, zero-width characters… but I agree that the plain space is the most common case and handling just it will catch 99% of cases.
- As long as some designer is happy with it, I'm happy with it.
- Using a label could have the advantage of revealing 0-width caracters, while my suggestion to highlight the invisible characters can't (or not easily), so it's not only simpler but better too, neat! :slight_smile:

Thanks a lot for taking care of that issue I reported!

Terminal: Open Nautilus as a new tab in an existing window

note.body:
We need a CLI switch for this. The switch would create a new tab with the folder passed as parameter if a nautilus window is already open, or it would open a new window with the folder if none was open prior. The whole purpose of this is to avoid a proliferation of nautilus windows. 

Sample use case: script called from the shell that will mount an filesystem and then will add a tab in the existing nautilus window with the filesystem root folder content. I actually use this construct and for X11 I used to use a horrible hack based on wmctrl to send keystrokes to the nautilus window to achieve the result. This no longer works in Wayland. Please add the --tab switch.

note.body:
Not exactly. Please refer https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/-/issues/3450#note_2252607, where the disk partition ordering is not followed, but only sorted by partition label. But, it's fine to me if we want to be sorted by partition order (it might be even better than sorting by partition label).

The main concern I was trying to address in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/-/issues/3450, was grouping random partitions from different disks via partition label sorting, which is of no meaning, and it get very confusing with just 2 - 3 disks.

target_title: Draft: grid-cell: Use dashed border for cut style

note.body:
Would it be feasible to have the outline span all the elements (instead of one outline for each element) for all elements that are neighbors? Would it use less resources, would it be easy to read, and would it look good?

Anyway, I mostly appreciate as little constant animations (animations that are just going constantly, not making a specific, limited change more pleasant to watch) as possible. It has a tendency to just distract and annoy for me personally. And in this instance I don't know if I see how walking ants would convey any more meaning, or be clearer, than just a dotted outline.

If there should be an animation, I think I prefer the idea from the linked discussion of animating the icons shrinking a little (just once, not back and forth). (If then – when you paste them somewhere else – they shrank further, out of existence (like getting sucked into the background/file manager), that could be pretty cool perhaps? :sweat_smile:)

target_title: After SMB server reboot while connected, Nautilus shows infinite error dialogs stealing focus and causing 100% GNOME Shell CPU usage

note.body:
I was able to reproduce this quite easily by visiting an smb share and authenticating.  Then I disconnected my laptop from the network and tried to navigate to another folder on the smb share.  I was also able to kill the nautilus process using the System Monitor GUI using just mouse clicks before it took down my whole system.

target_title: Sidebar sometimes breaks after clicking rearrangeable folders bookmarks too quickly

note.body:
The sidebar hangs in an uncompleted dnd operation. on_row_dragged calls gdk_drag_begin, which sends a wl_data_device.start_drag to gnome-shell. Sometimes gnome-shell does not send any wl_data_sources in response:
```
[3016373.990] {Default Queue} wl_pointer#29.button(283, 11747288, 272, 1)
[3016482.945] {Default Queue} wl_pointer#29.button(284, 11747397, 272, 0)
[3016484.687] {Default Queue}  -> wl_data_device_manager#8.create_data_source(new id wl_data_source#62)
[3016484.953] {Default Queue}  -> wl_data_source#62.offer("application/x-gtk-local-dnd")
[3016485.166] {Default Queue}  -> wl_data_source#62.set_actions(2)
[3016485.413] {Default Queue}  -> wl_data_device#32.start_drag(wl_data_source#62, wl_surface#38, wl_surface#60, 283)
```
This appears to happen only if gnome-shell sends an additional wl_pointer.button(n+1,,0) after the wl_pointer.button(n,,1), which caused the dnd source to send wl_data_device#32.start_drag(,,,n).

gnome-shell processes the wl_data_device.start_drag in mutter-46.5/src/wayland:
```
data_device_start_drag
  meta_wayland_seat_get_grab_info
    meta_wayland_pointer_get_grab_info:

if ((!require_pressed || pointer->button_count > 0) &&
      meta_wayland_pointer_can_grab_surface (pointer, surface, serial))
    ...
  return FALSE;
```
If pointer->button_count is 0, data_device_start_drag does not call meta_wayland_data_device_start_drag. The dnd operation hangs.

target_title: Crash when opening folders with js or json that have content

note.body:
I've been suffering the same problem since some days ago (\~1 or 2 months perhaps); I think that by updating the `shared-mime-info` package manually in my PoP!\_OS 22.04 the problem seems solved, be very careful applying this as I noticed some quirks (not worse than, as a developer, not being able to open any folder with .js or .json files with any tool, including nautilus) and who knows what else could/might be broken by this manual upgrade to this lib:

```
#prepare the tooling to build the new version
sudo apt install meson gettext libxml2-utils libglib2.0-dev
#download the newer version 2.3, 2.4 makes the OS behave weirdly.
wget https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/xdg/shared-mime-info/-/archive/2.3/shared-mime-info-2.3.tar.gz
tar -xzf shared-mime-info-2.3.tar.gz
cd shared-mime-info-2.4

#build and install the new version
meson _build -Dprefix=/usr
ninja -v -C _build install


#refresh the mime db
sudo update-mime-database /usr/share/mime
```

I had some problems that require creating missing folders and/or use sudo here and there; so use those as you need. Hopefully this will work for you.

target_title: Draft: grid-cell: Use dashed border for cut style

note.body:
The animation can be applied to hundreds of cells simultaneously, that's not comparable to a couple spinners in the sidebar.

I tried to copy-paste-modify code from AdwSpinner and applying to every cell, and it does 40 FPS in a big folder with all items cut as opposed to maximum refresh rate of the monitor while being idle.

As to using CSS, CSS borders are primitive. They don't allow custom dash length and offsets. I tried some [animated web CSS hacks](https://dev.to/chokcoco/fantastic-css-border-animation-5166) and it tanked the performance even with a single cell. Mind you, these creative hacks are for a square border.

target_title: Banner with enabled "Empty Trash" button even when there is no trash

note.body:
It can be disabled with gtk_widget_set_sensitive (I found this out because I'm giving this a shot).

The problem I'm running into now is the sheer number of cases to handle:
- [x] click into trash folder, it's already empty; disable the button
- [x] click into trash folder, empty it, then disable the button
- [ ] click into trash folder, empty it, then delete a file from somewhere else; reenable the button
- [ ] open the trash folder in two tabs/windows, clear the trash in one; both buttons should be disabled
- [ ] delete all the files in trash manually; the button should be disabled

I think the only way to do this properly is if there's some sort of global event (is this even possible with GObject?) that signals the fact that "there was some change to trash". I'm really new to the codebase (and GTK+ programming in general) so not very sure if there's such a thing? Would appreciate some pointers on this :)

note.body:
Non-hacky solutions:

1. Get localizers to write 10 translations for their locale, or write it ourselves through DL.
2. Add a dependency on libicu (C Lib) and use it.
3. Add a dependency on rust toolchain, build ICU4X (Rust Lib), compile the exact locale data needed, build the FFI interface, and call it from nautilus.

target_title: locale respecting timestamps for untranslated locales

note.body:
I remember this to be s technical issue, independent of what designers wanted, we weren't able to represent it accurately. So if there is a technically sound solution, we can get designers involved.

I feel this is an interesting approach. The `en_US` locale is still fully contained within the repo. However, the focus of this seems to be on a hack of setting an otherwise untranslated locale, so that text is still in `en_US` but formats are correct. IMO it would be more appropriate to add a translation for that locale and translate only the datetime strings there.

That being said, I feel that this still comes with an advantage for translators, as the default datetime values should work for most localizations and allow for respecting `LC_TIME` in those (I have not checked this, but from what I remember that was the good part of this MR). If they are not the suggested default most translators will not use them, since it's very technical terrain.

note.body:
Removing the shadows in thumbnail style improves performance, I've already had it removed in all previous screenshots. Removing any other CSS style, property, or class related to cells and grid view (minus 6px cells padding and "x: none" entries) doesn't really change anything.

If you look at the last screenshot, you notice that:
1. About 30% of the css code is related to emblems as it disappears when making them invisible
2. There are css invalidation in the list base section on the right of the profile screenshot:

`gtk_list_item_manager_insure_items()` -> `gtk_grid_view_split()` -> `gtk_list_base_get_border_spacing()` -> `gtk_css_node_get_style()` -> `gtk_css_node_do_ensure_style()` -> `gtk_css_node_invalidate()`

`gtk_list_item_manager_insure_items()` -> `gtk_widget_reposition_after()` -> `gtk_css_node_invalidate()` -> `gtk_css_node_invalidate_style()`

> But this is all in a state where the sysprof log is visible, so are we even hitting 100% CPU with the main thread?

There is about 70-85% usage of a single core at any given time, with the usage jumping around between CPUs.

target_title: No keyboard shortcut / mnemonic to directly focus the filename editing field in filechooser mode

note.body:
In the old file chooser dialog, `Ctrl-L` worked as a shortcut to jump to the filename entry, since the filename entry *was* the location entry. That was the main shortcut I used for it; I didn't realize that `Alt-N` also worked in the Save dialog (in part because the underline indicating shortcut mnemonics is hidden by default).

But Nautilus has changed the filename entry to be separate from the location entry, so while `Ctrl-L` still works for doing keyboard navigation to a different location, it definitely need a separate shortcut to jump directly to the filename entry.

The `Ctrl-L` shortcut also worked in the Open dialog as a way to select a file by typing its name (with completion). I don't think there's any equivalent functionality available in the new dialog? If there's a way to quickly start type-ahead find or non-recursive search from the keyboard, that would work as an alternative.

Hrm, 256x256x4bytes is 256kB per thumbnail. How many thumbnails are visible? Around 100? That would be 25MB to upload per frame. That's not trivial, but most computers should be able to deal with it.

That's something we landed shortly before 4.16.0 where we're multithreading image data copies - usually when we copy them to the GPU, because GPUs want RGBA data and images without transparency come in RGB format.

But: To be this big, you'd be uploading gigabytes of image data, and that feels not like something that should be happening. Can you see where [gdk_parallel_task_run](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/-/blob/d4ba57fc/gdk/gdkparalleltask.c#L53) is called in the tree - because that would be queueing it.

note.body:
Hi @shaaati, I see that you provided a screenshot of a Sysprof capture above, but it seems to be missing debug symbols, so we can't see the names of the functions. Maybe something new can be observed with a more complete capture and the latest versions of everything.

Please install all debug symbols / debuginfo packages for Nautilus and its dependencies (pro tip: use `dnf debuginfo-install the package names`), and profile version 47 using sysprof on the latest version of Fedora, Ubuntu (newer than 24.04), Arch or other distros that ship frame pointers enabled (as they are necessary to get [better data](https://blogs.gnome.org/chergert/2022/12/31/frame-pointers-and-other-practical-near-term-solutions/)). I saw you used Fedora before, so maybe you could try using Fedora 41 beta for this. In case it helps, here is [a general guide](https://fedoramagazine.org/performance-profiling-in-fedora-linux/) about how Sysprof works and how to interpret results.

A tip regarding large capture files: they compress really well, you could make a .tar.xz with Nautilus in addition to posting the screenshot.

What happens if we break that rule? It seems to work fine for me.\
I see on DamnedLies, that `gsettings-desktop-schemas` uses an `en_US` translation to have the default time format as 24h, but change the time format to 12h for en_US. So it's certainly not impossible to break that rule.

I think it is a fact that US date formatting is confusing and unreadable for a lot of people outside the US. Leaving date formatting, up to the translation, is not an option for user-friendliness.

target_title: Sidebar sometimes breaks after clicking rearrangeable folders bookmarks too quickly

note.body:
Can confirm this (sometimes) happens with the nightly flatpak version too, but apparently not version 46, so it seems to be a regression (or maybe I was just not lucky enough to be able to trigger it on 46).

Further remarks when the issue _does_ happen:

* It only removes the bookmark from the sidebar's view, but it does not actually delete the bookmark, i.e. when you restart Nautilus the bookmark is shown again where it was.
* The app does not actually hang, rather, the sidebar's interactivity breaks. You can still navigate using the pathbar / typing a path with `Ctrl+L`, so the main view is not broken, just that clicking items within the sidebar does not trigger their corresponding actions anymore.

target_title: Random Optimizations
Prevent Nautilus from thumbnailing FUSE filesystems

note.body: The GVfs project is not involved in this. FUSE filesystems are handled by the local implementation in GLib/GIO. If I am not mistaken the FUSE filesystem is marked as local, because it could be anything... and I am afraid there is currently no way to distinguish whether it is really local, or not. I'm afraid that marking FUSE as remote, or completely disabling thumbnails is not ideal as well. It would be nice to have some per-mount configuration...
